gov.usgs.traveltime

Class Decimate

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.traveltime.Decimate

  • public class Decimate
extends java.lang.Object
    Decimation methods used at various places in the travel-time package are implemented here. One integrated slowness grid for P and S is constructed and all other branches are derived by combining P and S. The resulting slowness sampling often suffers interpolation instability due to inhomogeneity in the grid. In practice, the best results are obtained by decimating the slowness grid such that the sampling in distance is reasonably uniform.
    Author:
    Ray Buland

    • Method Detail

      • decXFast

        public double[] decXFast(double[] p,
                         double[] tau,
                         double[] xRange,
                         double xMin)
        The "fast" method was used in the FORTRAN real-time travel-time calculation for the up-going branches only to save time. The "slow", but more precise decimation was only used in the front end table generation. Although, the slower method is recommended for all uses in the Java version, the fast version has been implemented for debugging comparison purposes.
        Parameters:
        p - Normalized ray parameter grid
        tau - Normalized tau on the same grid
        xRange - Normalized distance at the branch end points
        xMin - Normalized minimum distance interval desired
        Returns:
        Decimated, normalized ray parameter grid

      • getDecTau

        public double[] getDecTau()
        Get the tau values corresponding to the decimated ray parameter grid.
        Returns:
        Decimated, normalized tau on the decimated ray parameter grid

      • calcX

        public double calcX(double[] p,
                    double[] tau,
                    double[] xRange,
                    int i)
        Return distance as a function of tau (distance is minus the derivative of tau). The method uses a simple three point approximation of the derivative except at the end points where distance is already known.
        Parameters:
        p - Normalized ray parameter grid
        tau - Normalized tau on the same grid
        xRange - Normalized distance at the branch end points
        i - Grid point where the derivative is required
        Returns:
        Distance corresponding to tau(p_i)
